prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
C18O (2-1) to trace Keplerian disks SO (5_6-4_5) to trace accretion shock H2CO (3-2) to trace infall motion CO (2-1) to trace outflow N2H+ (3-2) to trace chemistry Continuum to trace disk mass
Keplerian disks around our targets typically have rotational velocities >0.5-1.3 km/s at radii < 50 AU. Hence, we request a velocity reolution of ~0.2 km/s to resolve the velocity features. The basewidth of one spectral window is much wider than the expected line width, which is typically 2 to 5 km/s.

We aim to resolve Keplerian disks around our targets. Our targets all likely have disks with their diameter > 100 AU. Therefore, we request an angular reolsution of ~0.4", corresponding to 100 AU at the distance of our targets. Our targets are all Class 0 protostars. They unlikely can have disks larger than 1000 AU, i.e., 4". Therefore, all the disks around our targets can be recovered with the 12m array.

We aim to measure radial profiles of rotation around our targets. The accuracy of measuring relative position is approximately beam/(S/N). We select targets likely having disks with their diameter > 100 AU. Therefore, we request a spatial resolution of ~100 AU. At S/N > 5, we are able to measure rotational velocities at several different radii to identify Keplerian rotation. The expected peak line intensity is >47 mJy, and we request a noise level of ~6.3 mJy to achieve S/N > 5. Keplerian disks around our targets typically have rotational velocities >0.4-1.3 km/s at radii < 50 AU. Hence, we request a velocity resolution of 0.2 km/s to resolve these velocity features.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Protostellar mass and mass accretion rate are two key parameters in star formation processes. However, both are observationally not well characterized for protostars at the main accretion phase. This project is aiming at measuring mass of 10 Class 0 protostars from resolved Keplerian rotation with ALMA in C18O (2-1) at 0.4 (~100 AU) resolutions. The targets are selected from our SMA pilot study. Based on their infall and rotation on a 1000 AU scale observed with the SMA, they likely exhibit Keplerian disks with radii > 50 AU, which can be resolved with the proposed ALMA observations. We have developed a method to measure rotational profiles and identify Keplerian disk. With the directly measured protostellar mass, we are able to break the degeneracy in bolometric luminosity, which is proportional to protostellar mass times mass accretion rate, to more precisely estimate mass accretion rate. With these two quantities, we will investigate the tentative correlations between protostellar mass, mass accretion rate, and protostellar envelope mass, seen in our SMA pilot study. That can hint the evolution of mass accretion rate from the Class 0 to I stages.
